comments.text:
+john brown
Oh, sorry.  It was in response to your gun magazine question.  The U.S. 
currently has no bullet number limit for magazines anymore.  They did under 
Clinton, but it expired under Bush.
Some states within the U.S. do have their own magazine size limits, however.

I could probably help with your emissions question, also.  People can 
"build their own cars" and have them registered and inspected, but people 
rarely do that.
What they do is take an existing VIN (serial number for a car basically) 
that is registered with the state and they attached it to a car that they 
build and then they can get plates by claiming it is the stock vehicle that 
the state thinks that it is.    In most cases what they just did is 
technically illegal, but often is not enforced.  Again, it can depend on 
the state that they do it in.  Some states care more than others.
comments.author: l337pwnage

comments.text:
+l337pwnage I don't live in the US so everything you wrote is intelligible 
to a US citizen but all Greek to an outsider, but thanks for replying.
comments.author: john brown

comments.text:

are plenty of guys in the vintage racing scene that have ultra rare cars, 
such as the Maserati Birdcages, and they use a modern frame and store the 
original (just in case they crash).

comments.text:
+0pnMnded I took notes from the video.I am no expert on American motors I 
just think this car is ace..
comments.author: sixfootbear

comments.text:
+sixfootbear Ok, I must have misunderstood about the speed but the problem 
here is that the numbers are all wrong on the engine, I've checked White, 
REO and Diamond T and there isn't a gasoline inline six with those numbers 
to be found, even the diesels and dual fueled ones don't have anywhere near 
that torque. The only thing there is to go on is that it is a Reo engine 
built for the White motor division from a '51-52 White water truck. Another 
thing is that Diamond REO part, the companies didn't merge until way later 
in the '60's I believe but that's not really an issue though because the 
plate on the side says it's an REO built for White. If the engine had been 
rebuilt it would be understandable (almost) but they said it had never been 
cracked open. It's frustrating because I like the car too and I really want 
to know more about the engine... Whatever it is, I like it too, seems like 
it would be a real beast.
comments.author: 0pnMnded

comments.text:
+0pnMnded Mike said he only dare go at 45 mph through the canyons as he 
slides on the seat.The engine is 1952 Diamond Reo tractor motor. The 
drivetrain is from a 1951 White water truck. That bit is easy.The 1951 
motor could have been replaced in 1952 with a new  engine. 275 bhp. 1640 
foot pounds torque.The body is a 1931 Ford. 
I love it..
comments.author: sixfootbear

comments.text:
+Kj B He said it came from a White water truck which I was assuming he 
meant a fire pumper but I don't know, he says a lot of things that don't 
make sense, like it being a '52 engine in a '51 truck. I don't know where 
they came up with Diamond REO because like you said, they had not merged 
yet so who knows... Here's a link to the engine I was talking about that 
looks like this one. It's an REO 331 Gold Comet, it only puts out 128 hp, 
have no clue about the torque but I'm sure it's not 1600 fp...
http://www.curbsideclassic.com/curbside-classics-american/curbside-classic-1952-reo-f-22-dump-truck-i-can-dig-it/
 
Now he also mentions that the car only did around 45 mph which would make 
sense because if you put an engine like that in a truck, you're gonna have 
to have some insanely low gears just to get it moving and I may be wrong 
but I don't think they would ever be able to use 1:1 ratio because of the 
hp, there's just not enough power there for a truck so based on what he 
said about the donor truck and it not going over 45 mph and the engine 
never being opened, I think it's pretty safe to say that the numbers are 
most definitely wrong and that we can officially call BS on this one.
comments.author: 0pnMnded

comments.text:
Apparently the pictured tractor to the article I found was NOT the 
Tractor...
comments.author: Kj B

comments.text:
Hmmm. I think this guy did in fact butcher the numbers. Possibly to get the 
gear heads interested in it. If there is anything I have learned, it is 
that most things on the internet tend to be incorrect. If the best diesel 
truck engine you can buy for a Ford 450 now generates somewhere along 
700-800 Ft Pnds of Torque. Only because of the extreme technology behind 
it... Well anyways: If the Military has these M1 Abrahms tanks that can 
move at 42 MPH carrying 62 tons... ... Nevermind, pretty useless. Ok! Here 
is what I found off of the internet. How much power does it take to move a 
fully loaded semi and trailer? A Detroit Diesel DD15 14.8-liter inline 
six-cylinder engine weighs 2880 pounds, or 345 pounds more than a Mini 
Cooper. This colossal powerplant makes up to 560 hp and 1850 lb-ft of 
torque, and at just 1200 rpm the engine produces more than 1500 lb-ft of 
torque.
Most turbocharged diesel engines put out between 1200 and 2050 lb-ft to 
keep all that weight moving. 950-2100ft/lb. in stock form. They can be 
turned up or tuned for more power. A C15 Cat is rated up to 625 Hp and 2050 
Tq. It is a 928ci motor and weighs 3090lbs. It depends on the motor (Cat, 
Cummins, Detroit). There are many different displacements available as well 
as horsepower ratings (the higher the HP the higher the TQ). Many of the 
trucks run a 450-575hp rating, depending on type of truck and what it is 
being used for.

So these engines that put out that kind of Torque weigh a LOT. Let's check 
Tractor Engines.

Here is something interesting and truthful I encountered. 

Like we say in the car business, torque wins races, HP sells cars.

I would like to add something that my teacher taught me. "Torque gets you 
going, RPM keeps you going"

Here is something interesting I found. Perhaps it is based off of After 
gear reductions... (30,000 Ft Lbs of Torque!) 
http://tractors.findthebest.com/l/570/Landini-Rex-110
Apparently it has 15 different Forward gears.... So, in my opinion... 1 
Gear Ratio, 1 other Gear Ratio, then a Stable Rear Diff. Ratio. 
 The best I could come up with through simple mathematics is 31x31x31 To 
increase 1 Ft Pound of Torque to about 30,000. Let's see here... Hmmm... 
Let's say this tractor started off with 300 Ft Pounds of Torque. Some what 
reasonable. Based off of the comparative size of the driver to the Tractor 
in the given picture. So, in order for us to turn 300 Ft Pound of Torque 
into 30,000 Ft Pnds, we need to increase it by 100. Let's call the rear 
Diff a simple 4 to one Rear Diff for the sake of this being easy. so, 
100/4=20 Let's say that the 3 speeds (LL, LH, HH: Low Low, Low High, High 
High) are 3:1, 2:1 and 1:1, respectively. So, 20/3=6.66 Which mean that the 
five primary gears need to have first gear to be a 6.66 :1 gear Ratio. 
Hmmm... 

Shall we chalk this one up to a simple: This thing was never dynoed 
properly?
comments.author: Kj B

comments.text:
+Kj B  I think you may be right, they may have just plugged in the wrong 
numbers. I checked again but didn't find anything, I looked at White, REO, 
Diamond T and about half a dozen others as well... The block says it was 
built by the REO division of the White Motor Company but none of the truck 
engines I've found so far have had anything near the numbers this guy 
claims. I found an engine that looked similar to this one but the hp and 
torque were all wrong, I did find a forum where some guy said that he 
thought REO had built a truck engine rated around 280 hp, but he didn't 
know anything other than that. REO also built trucks for the military so 
there may be some information floating around out there but I don't know 
how it could be found considering the only thing ''known'' about it is that 
it's a gasoline inline six with a shitload of torque... Basically the only 
I've learned from all of this is that REO was founded by Ransom E. Olds, 
who also founded Oldsmobile and that REO built trucks for haulin stuff and 
one of those trucks was named Speedwagon and that's where the band REO 
Speedwagon got their name and that Diamond REO is where the country band 
Diamond Rio got their name, they just changed the spelling...
comments.author: 0pnMnded

comments.text:
Wait a second... This isn't a diesel?
Ok, after some research I came up with this. It is supposedly an Engine 
from a 1952 Diamond-Reo Tractor... Then I found this on Wikipedia: Diamond 
Reo Trucks was an American truck manufacturer. In 1967, Diamond T and Reo 
Trucks were combined to form the Diamond Reo Trucks Division of the White 
Motor Corporation. So, that may be why you are having issues finding 
information on this engine, because there is according to this, no such 
thing as a 1952 Diamond-Reo. I think how it is producing 1600 FT Pnds of 
Torque... That was with out subtracting the Gear ratios and Rear Diff.
comments.author: Kj B

comments.text:
+Kj B  I don't doubt the torque or horse power, I've been looking all 
morning trying to figure out what engine this thing has in it but can't 
find anything so I don't know its displacement, stroke or anything but I 
know that Inline engines generally produce more torque than V6's and in 
some cases V8's, the horse power could be up there too because there's no 
telling what the displacement is. I can imagine that if it has that much 
torque and that mileage, the connecting rods must be about 10 ft long with 
about a 2 ft stroke, well, maybe not quite that extreme but I'm sure it has 
some pretty damn long arms and one hell of a stroke to produce that much 
torque and not be completely worn out at 1 million miles. I've seen Volvo's 
with a million miles on the odometer and their engines probably aren't even 
half as beefy as this one is. The thing that really surprises me though is 
that it isn't a diesel, for some reason I could just imagine smelling raw 
diesel pouring out of the exhaust and covering the entire car and the 
driver with diesel and soot whilst leaving an oil slick behind it the whole 
time I was watching this.
comments.author: 0pnMnded

comments.text:
Tractor Motors were not built for horse power, they were built for Torque, 
High Torque does a LOT less wear then  High Horsepower.. I doubt this thing 
generates 275 Horsepower though, or 1640 Ft Lbs of Torque, something was 
forgotten on the Dyno that day... I think the Gear Ratios/Rear Diff Ratio 
was incorrectly inputted on that day... But yeah, 1640 Ft Lbs of Torque... 
The case never cracked open and I am not seeing any obvious Performance 
Modifications..... I am sorry, I just can't bring myself to believe that it 
generates 1600 Horse Power from the engine alone... Beautiful car, cool 
owner but.. I am sorry, but I have just never heard of such a high Torque 
engine... from the 1950s. I mean the amount of wear that HAD to have 
occurred... IDK.. Maybe it is Satan's Hotrod.. Only explanation... >.<
comments.author: Kj B

top_comment.text: That is an incredible engine! straight six for the win!﻿
top_comment.author: NITROUSINJECTEDFISHY

comments.text:
+Ben Kerchner You are wrong and I don't think you know what an exhaust 
manifold is. At 1:56 is the exhaust side, you will count 6 exhaust runners 
connecting the head to the downpipe, which connects to the 6 individual 
chrome exhaust tips. That part which does all the connecting is an exhaust 
manifold. At 4:42 is the intake side, you will find there is not a manifold 
connecting the head to the exhaust tips in any way. In the same location on 
this side of the engine, you will see the 6 gray plug wires going to the 
head where there must then be 6 spark plugs, and the other kind of manifold 
known as an intake manifold to which the carb is mounted. The "exhaust 
manifold" you're referring to on this side is actually just exhaust tips, 
probably welded on for show, or connected to the other side with a plenum 
box of some kind underneath.

   This is an engine with one bank if cylinders, see how it's a straight 
line, not a "V"?  Since there are 6 exhaust runners on the exhaust side, 
and 6 plugs on the intake side, we can assume it is a inline or straight 6. 
But if that's too complex for you, count the wires on the distributor at 
2:20 you will find there are 7. 1 for each cylinder and 1 for the coil. 
This is absolutely a straight six. I'm not sure why you would think this is 
a V10...V10s have two banks of cylinders and two heads. There is nothing 
that would suggest that statement is true, even in the eyes of a novice car 
guy. I can seen how a novice would think this is a v12 maybe because there 
are 12 exhaust tips...but it's neither.

  And there are many manufacturers of inline sixes that produce more torque 
than this thing even does. Including Mac, Cummins, and International to 
name a few. They are the best engine for pulling due to their torque 
potential and their perfectly balanced crankshafts. I am a diesel 
serviceman, I know what I'm looking at.

   Ever seen a V10 with one bank of cylinders, 7 wires going off the 
distributor, 6 exhaust ports on one side of the single head, and 6 spark 
plugs? Me neither, class dismissed.
comments.author: NITROUSINJECTEDFISHY

comments.text:
I'm pretty sure its not a straight six.  Have you ever seen straight six 
with the exhaust manifold coming out of both sides?  And no straight six 
makes that much torque.  pretty sure its a 10 cyl.
comments.author: Ben Kerchner

comments.text: CRAZY KID!!

top_comment.text:
don't believe  torque  numbers claimed(the best ford ever made was 
~200Hp@225FT/lbs not counting the torque amplifier(this is where you could 
make the insane numbers but you basically trade wheel speed and RPM for it)
tho with a full package build you might beable to get 300Hp and 275Ft/lbs  ﻿
top_comment.author: rjc862003

comments.text:
+Tom Doby  yea there is no way in hell that greasy old sprew factory makes 
1600FT/lbs without the torqe AMP from the tractor a torq amp is basically a 
giant spring wound around a drum
comments.author: rjc862003

comments.text:
yea rj they claimed 1600 ft/lbs of torque and what i thought i heard them 
say 200 or so horsepower? i'm not a genious but wow
comments.author: Tom Doby

captions.text:
MIKE MUSTO: It's got over 1,600
pound-feet of torque.

It's made from a combination of
old tractor parts and light

poles and has the ability to
actually tow New York to Los
Angeles if you so choose.

And I have absolutely no idea
how I'm going to drive it.
Welcome to Big Muscle.
My name is Mike Musto.

Each week, I travel the country
with the goal of

showcasing the best and baddest
muscle cars and hot
cars around.

Every car has a past, and
every owner a story.

Welcome to the world
of "Big Muscle."

Here, at "Big Muscle,"
we love rat rods.

To some, there's just rolling
rod boxes cobbled together

from scrap metal and
baling wire.

But look closer, and many times
you'll find that the

workmanship, artistry and
overall uniqueness of these

vehicles far outshines many
big money builds.

The frame rails, for instance,
are made from old municipal
light poles.

The gas, clutch and brake pedals
are a mix of an old

spider gear with a few
nuts and bolts
thrown in for good measure.

And the little scoops
on the hood?

Yeah, they're from a pair
of old steel-toed boots.

This car is about as far out as
they come, which is exactly
why we needed to film it.

HENRY KESSLER: What we have here
is a 1931 Ford, with a

1952 Diamond Rio
tractor motor.

The motor, the trans and the
rear tires are all from a 1951

whites water truck, which
is old farm equipment.

The motor has 275 horse,
with right around 1,640
foot-pounds of torque.
The frame rails are light poles
from the city of Hollywood.

They act as resonators
for the exhaust.

The wish bones are
fence posts.

The headlights are
from a '42 Buick.
It's a real Duvall windshield.

The motor's got over
a million miles.

The cases have never
been cracked open.

It smokes and pukes oil, but it
runs like a top, and it'll
do another million miles.

MIKE MUSTO: So Henry, I'll
be honest with you.

I'm a little bit nervous about
driving this thing.

Take me through the process of
what we've got, what the

switches do and so
on and so forth.
HENRY KESSLER: OK.

Well, you've got your standard
clutch, brake, throttle.

To start the power on the
car, there's one switch.
Lift it up.

That'll turn on the pump
for the airbags.

It'll turn on the
charging system.

Then make sure you're
in neutral.
It's one button.
[CAR STARTS]

HENRY KESSLER: It
starts right up.

MIKE MUSTO: It's
like a hybrid!
HENRY KESSLER: Yeah.
It's my Prius.
First button up is front bags.

Second button to the
side is rear bags.
MIKE MUSTO: OK.
And that's the whole deal?

HENRY KESSLER: You're
ready to go?

MIKE MUSTO: Today's going
to be a cool day, man.

It's going to be a
really cool day.

HENRY KESSLER: Should
be interesting.

MIKE MUSTO: Yeah, it should
be interesting.
HENRY KESSLER: We're rolling!

MIKE MUSTO: All right, so
here's something you
don't see every day.

My big ass driving a
1931 Ford tractor.
I'll be honest with you.
I've driven a lot of stuff.
This isn't one of them.
The body is a 1931 Ford.
Transmission--
it's a five-speed.

And believe it or not, it likes
to rev. We don't need
to, but it does.

The main job is to piss off
Prius owners, scare women,

scare children, and basically,
just have fun.

I mean, the thing
is unbelievable.
And it's a bitch to drive.

I'm not intimidated
by a lot of stuff.
But this thing?

This thing intimidates
the hell out of me.

I mean, some of the
things that--

you've got to take notice
over this thing, right?

I didn't know where
the gas tank was.

Then I learned, it's literally
right here.
It's a six-gallon.
It's an old settling tank.

And it was put in under
the dashboard.

You know, so this way, if you
crash in a head-on collision,

the motor comes straight back
in and you hit the gas tank.
And you just blow up.

The frame on this car, there are
stress parts of the body

that are welded to
the gas tank.

Not really sure how
I feel about it.
All I know is that it works.

We all know, obviously, this
is not a canyon carver, but

believe it or not, it does
actually go around a corner.

I don't know how he's going to
stay in his seat, because you
slide all over the place.

And you're wrenching
this wheel.
I mean, look at my hands!
This is nuts.

I'm going to come out
of this thing.

I'm going to be black
from top to bottom.
And you know what?

I'm going to love every
minute of it.
[LAUGHS]

HENRY KESSLER: The air bags are
off of a RTD bus which is
a old LA transit system.

There's one dead center
right here, and
there's two in the back.

It raises up right around
9 and 1/2 inches.

There's a shock on each side
of the bag and then one on
each side over here.

And then there's two
in the back.

And that's just to kind of
keep the car stable.

But it pretty much all rides
on the bags themselves.

And then the wishbones are
connected to a Heim joints,

which are off of a landing
gear off of a Lear jet.

So this thing's built
bulletproof.
It's made to run.

And you look at it, and you're
like this thing's not going to
go anywhere.

But aside from you sliding
around, this thing's on rails.

And it'll do a canyon
all day long.

I mean, granted, it'll do it at
45, but it'll do it at 45
pulling your house.

MIKE MUSTO: You know, this
thing, this grenade shifter,
let me tell you something.
It's a bomb for a reason.
Whoa!
[LAUGHS]

You go into these turns,
and part of you is
holding on for dear life.

Part of me was waiting to see
if there's something around

the next corner. 'Cause if you
hit it, you're finished.

There is literally a piece of
mesh leather on the bottom of

my ass and his ass, and as soon
we turn, we're sliding
all over the place.

As far as back support,
I have news.
I'll definitely be in the
chiropractor's office on Monday.

Because I mean, this
is ridiculous.
Oh, yeah!

See that short shifter
right in the car.
HENRY KESSLER: Keep rolling.

MIKE MUSTO: I'm like
a professional now.
[LAUGHS]
Holy [BEEP].
I want one of these.

I want one of these, and I want
to drive through downtown

Berkeley with black smoke
belching out of the six pipes.

We got to find a Prius owner
and just suck him in.
That's what I want to do.

And you got to picture
this, right?

We're up in the Hollywood
hills.

And this is some of the
most expensive real
estate on the planet.

And I feel like as we're driving
by, people are just

feeling like their property
values are going down, which I

really don't give a crap
about, because
I think it's hilarious.

I mean, never have I driven a
vehicle where I literally rest

my hands on my knees
to drive it.

And you want to talk
about fun.

Since we've only got a
six-gallon tank, we're going

to get some fuel because, like
we said, wow, this really
doesn't hold any.

And if we want to keep
shooting, we got to
fill this sucker up.
I mean, this is nuts.
I mean, we've got gas.
We're all over the place.

It's crazy when you think a
straight six-cylinder gas

engine could literally make
1,600 pound-feet of torque.
That's nuts!
That's simply nuts.
It's a mind-boggling thing.

The best is next to us, we've
got a Fisker hybrid.

You know, the company that
went out of business?
Those guys.

It's kind of funny, this thing's
been around for 100
years or whatever.
We're still going strong.

And that thing's been around
for six months.
It's not doing too well.
This car is a spectacle.

It's the fly in the ointment
and the black
sheep of the family.

Therefore, we could think of
no better place to take it

than down to the most
look-at-me strip
to the United States--
Rodeo Drive.

Not only do we get looks and
comments from everyone, but we

even got up close and
personal with one
of the local residents.

MIKE MUSTO: How do you
read this day?

We are rolling down Hollywood
Boulevard in something that

people just don't
know what to do.

Yeah, I mean, what you guys
can't see right now is that we
just stopped.

And the crowd of people--
what's up, guys--

that just crowded around
this thing.
It's insane.

I mean, how do you beat
Hollywood Boulevard in a rat
rod that looks like this?
You want a picture?
Absolutely take a picture.
Yeah.

One of the best details about
this car is not the car
itself, but it's owner.

Henry is a guy who loves
to see reactions.

He likes the people, young and
old, smile and scratch their
head at this thing.

And his philosophy about the
car couldn't be better.

HENRY KESSLER: If you've got a
hot rod that you put $150,000

into it and $20,000 paint job,
you don't want anybody
breathing on it.

You're not going
to take it out.
This thing, I could care less.
I enjoy it.
I love it.

It would kill me if something
ever happened to it.

But when I go to a car show,
I'm the only one that tells

people, oh yeah, you're taking
a picture next to my car.

Why don't you throw
your kid in there?
Are you serious?
Absolutely.

You know, that's how you get
the next generation into

wanting to get into
the car culture.

MIKE MUSTO: I honestly
don't know what to
say about this car.
You look at it.
You drive it.
And it beats you to death.

The clutch is like pushing in a
sledgehammer every time you
try to engage it.

It belches black smoke and soot
and dirt, like literally

the likes of which
I've never seen.

Like you see this is
like a white cloth?

And if I go like this, that's
no longer white.

Guys, thanks for tuning in to
another episode of "Big

Muscle." Obviously, email us at
DriveBigMuscle@gmail.com.

And I'm going to take a shower
in a little while, because I'm
just dirty.

And like I said, worth every
second of the day.
Thanks.

The best is everybody
that just looks.

People have no concept of what
to make in this thing.
How you doing?
What's going on?
Good to see you.
Hi, how you doing?
Good to see you.
Hi, how you doing?
How are you?
Good to see you.
How are you?
Good to see you.
Nice to see you.
Well, welcome to Hollywood.
